text: [2/4/17] Draught/Bottle at Extreme Beer Fest in Boston. Dark brown. Bourbon, vanilla, fruits, sweet, malt, caramel, a bit of alcohol.

Poured into a snifter, the appearance was a semi-dark brown color with a little creamy colored head leaving some sticky lacing.
The aroma had some roast, berries, brown sugar and caramel/toffee malts.
The flavor copied the aroma pretty much spot on, leaning to the sweet side and adding some nuts. Subtle nutty to berry aftertaste hitting the finish, somewhat sticky, but slightly acceptable.
On the body, this one was medium bodied with a fair sessionability about it. Mild carbonation and the ABV felt good.
Overall, nicely done strong ale, but seemed to lean towards the English side more. Didnt seem like there were enough or even any hoppiness in the aroma and flavor to be an American styled one.
Consistently one of my favorite beers since I first had it in 2009. The fruitiness of the berries excellently accents the malty and bourbony sweet/caramel notes. Wondrous.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is roast and berries. Medium mouth, roasted malt, light booze, dark fruit, candy sugar, good.

Location: Bottle shared at Max and Andys Tasting, 2/28/15, Batch 1


Aroma: The aroma is bourbon, fruit, vanilla, and a bit of spice

Appearance: The pour is dark brown, and has a fairly small head

Flavor: The taste is pretty similar, lots of bourbon, a little fruit, and a little spice

Palate: The body is fairly full, with a good amount of heat still present considering the age

Overall Impression: 
This one seems to have pretty nicely actually. I was surprised that the heat wasnt more gone that it was. The fruitiness adds a nice component.

22 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany), pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out strong bourbon, oak and light tart fruits. Flavour brings out lots of bourbon, lightly tart dark fruits, followed by oaky wood. Complex and drinkable, with the booze very well-hidden. Wonderful stuff.

Bottle share thanks to beechner224. Pours a dark brown, nearly black, opaque color with small light tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, roast and some smoke character, light bourbon notes and barrel character. Very sweet, fruity, cherry/berries, spices, bourbon. Develops well as it warms.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown, almost black, tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, some mixed fruitiness. Taste is surprinshly light, some fruity sweetness. Dont get much barrel in the taste. Maybe needs to warm up. Tasty though.

1/3/2014. 22 oz. bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black with a short tan head. Aromas are bourbon, dark fruit, roasted malt. Thin mouth feel though and flavors have a bit of sourness or high acidity, almost metallic which throws it off a bit.

Batch 4 and 5 side by side. Pours a deep brown, near black with thin diminishing tan head - batch 5 with a little more head and longer lasting - and soapy lace. Batch 4 smells pretty windy, grape, tart cherries. Batch 5 more like molasses and candi sugar. Medium body and tartness. Batch 4 more tart, slight cola, cherry.

750 purchased at the brewery. Poured into a Duvel tulip. Pours a purple brown color. Fantastic aroma. Mild funk mild bourbon mild berries. All melded together. Mouthfeel is very thin. Taste is very fruity. Bourbon is barely present which I like. Great melding of all flavors. I'd like to get a bit thicker mouthfeel and more Belgian flavor but very good overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours a dark brown, sweet berries, very thin. Decent malts, some bourbon. Really didnt like this that much.

Batch 4.
Aroma is fairly well balanced between dark malt, fruit and barrels. Malt is fairly toasty with some chocolate notes to it. Nice vinous fruit quality with berries and tart cherries. Medium light oak and bourbon notes. 
Pours a very dark brown, pretty much black with a mocha head of moderate size and thickness. The head quickly recedes to the edges where it lingers. 
Flavor is noticeably fruitier than the aroma and the malt note is more chocolatey than roasty. Starts with a slightly sweet but tart berry note with hints of cherries and plums. Moderate chocolate with light roast. Medium low bitterness with no hop flavor. Medium low bourbon and oak note. Moderate alcohol in finish with lingering berries and chocolate. 
Mouthfeel is medium full to full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low tannic astringency with medium alcohol warmth. This definitely has some higher alcohols to it. 
Overall a nice flavorful beer, but it is definitely a winter warmer and leaves you feeling flush. I think they did a great job balancing all the flavors from the fruit, malt and barrels. One thing I might note is that I dont get much yeast character, but Im not sure how much I was expecting.

Batch 4
Tasted on 8/1/13 from a capped 750mL bottle obtained in a trade quite a while ago, this one has been in the cellar for a while. Pours an extremely dark, cloudy brown with an average light brown head that slowly recedes to an average collar of lace. The nose is dominated by vanilla, caramel, and toffee bourbon, with dark molasses, burnt brown sugar, some dark roast, and a nice fruity note. The flavor starts off with all of the dark roast up front, moving to the much more pronounced fruity flavor, and finishing with more of the bourbon and dark malt. The body is full with average, smooth carbonation, and a very long fruity and full of dark roast and bourbon finish.

A defined bourbon scent, carmel malts, oak, and slight fruit scent. It has an even better taste. The bourbon blends well with the fruit flavor. I picked up on the sweet malts, berries, plums, and bourbon. The Nor Easter impacts the palate but leaves a pleasant refreshing and relaxing smooth finish.

Batch 5 Bottle; Pour is dark brown with ruby highlights into this glass - a modest khaki head initial, with average to poor retention and light lacing present. The nose is light bourbon barrel, berries, dark fruit, caramel, cocoa, and bread. The flavor profile is berry dominant initial, surprising actually. It does balance out a bit with dark malts, bread, bourbon notes, albeit lighter - the mouthfeel is smoother than expected for the style, and the abv is masked fairly well here. It loses something near the finish - but its a nice brew.

A - Pours a dark black with just a hint of brown and a finger of frothy khaki colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted caramel and chocolate malts, vanilla, oak, Bourbon, berries, dark fruit, a touch of spices, and some booze.

T - Starts off with some caramel and chocolate malts with some vanilla, dark fruit, and berries. Through the middle, the oak and Bourbon come through alongside some more berries and dark fruit and a touch of spices. The finish is a mix of sweet dark fruits and berries, vanilla, oak, Bourbon, caramel malts, a bit of spices, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. The bourbon adds some nice complexity around a bit malty base beer.

Trade with Bobertkuekn. Black pour, thick, moderately high head, very nice lacing. Aroma is very light, and very reminiscent of a sour ale. Flavor is lightly sour, not sweet, relatively uncomplex, slightly vinous. Light mouthfeel, but not thin. The alcohol is completely hidden. Very hard to pin this beer down because it really is different from anything Ive had. Essentially it comes off as a light sour ale, with some subtle notes of wine and oak. Find very little if any bourbon in this. Rating is somewhat low, but I could see warming up to this over time. An interesting brew.

2010 Vintage. Enjoyed in a wine glass at near fridge temperature. 

A - No head at all. Murky plum brown with nice alcohol legs on the swirl. 

S - Raisins, figs, brown sugar and other very sweet dark fruits. Maybe dried figs is more close to what this smells like. Small maltiness but not a lot of bourbon as I would expect. 

T - Very malty up front. Sort of thick in the malt taste with the middle being the start of a box full of raisins. But theres this acetic funky lacto sort of taste in the center. Its unsuprising and not what I was expecting. Finish is oaky, hints of bourbon and some vanilla with a sweet departure of tastes.

M - 15% carbonation on the mouth swish, medium body and funky sweet solidly sippable drinkable finish.

O - This is a great beer. Enjoyable. Solid. Wishing there was a bit more carbonation.

-- Poured a clear, nearly opaque dark brown. One finger to half finger of light brown head. Good head retention and good lacing associated with this as drinking. Lots of spotty lacing. 

S-- Did not expect tartness to this at all. Quite odd. Little bit of a sour/ tart smell to this. A bit like a sweet tart. Elderberry evident off the bat and in the back of the nose get touches of bourbon. Grape and bubble gum in the nose as well. 

T-- More sour and tartness. Grape, bubblegum, oak, bits of bourbon in the back but very soft. Thought a La Chouffe but a sour version of it. Interesting. 

M-- Light and bubbly, has a very clean, crisp and dry finish to this. Medium feel and medium carbonation. Pretty easy to drink really. Once got over the tart smell and taste a pretty easy beer to drink. Alcohol well hidden. 

O-- Not what I expected but good. Well hidden 12% beer. Rich and full but light. Am guessing the triple fermentation to that. Touches of grape and bourbon make this quite interesting to me.

Batch 4 bottle from Josh - thanks!  Pours extremely dark brown (nearly black) with a dark tan head that fades out to a slick.  Aroma is sour fruit of some type up front with the bourbon and sweet malt, including raisin and perhaps some spice, toward the finish.  Taste is an interesting combination of sour (but not infected) fruit with heavier malt, spices, and a clean, but slightly biting bourbon character into the finish.  Mouthfeel is light and clean.  Nice beer.

750 ml bottle to oversized snifter (shared with the wife; 2011 vintage).  Looks good; dark with low carbonation and thin lacing (visible after swirling).  Smells good too; wood and elderberries with sour notes.  Tastes like it smells with bourbon present.

Ahhhh yes.  Was reminded last night that I consumed this years back in my basement with after4ever.  Batch #1!  Big bourbon filled berry nose.  Complex all around...elements of bourbon, port, berry, chocolate, dark fruits, and more.  Dense and thick.  I remember us all oogling over this one and knowing that we could never get anymore.  Sounds like they may have done some more batches since though??  One for the books!

Bottle, many thanks coldbrewky. Dark red brown color with huge beige head. Aroma of dark berries, caramel, some flowers, pear, oak. Taste, elderberries, roasted malt, chocolate, bourbon, liquorice, wood. Long sour finish. Nice, tasty beer.

Pours a barely translucent deep sable. Aroma has notes of maple syrup and bourbon. Mouth-filling flavor has a sour apple overtone plus caramel, smoky and licorice notes. Body is average but has plenty of fizz.

Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma has light chocolate and a bit of fruit...notable sour notes...raisins and light bourbon.  Flavor has a soury fruitiness and light bourbon vanilla character...mild chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and creamy with a warming oaky finish that hints of bourbon.  Not a fan of the soury qualities here.
Batch 5 shared with coldbrewky. dark amber color. sweet burbon, light clove, elderberry, bourbon,  flowers, a tad tart. complex to a point of over kill. slightly drying mouth.

A gift from SJ. This was a nice change of pace. I always liked the American strong, but I dont know why I dont buy more of them.

Any way, heres what I loved about this one.

The pleasant  caramel malt, bourbon, wood, dark fruit with asoury / tart finish. Very enjoyable.
Tastes like a dark chocolate berry.  Very nice appearance, but a bit too tart for my liking.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, oak/wood, vanilla, & dark fruit; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit (notably berries), raisons, and spice; Finish is slightly sour/tart; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, nice bourbon quality to it - very good stuff.

Nor Easter pours a little bit like a stout.  Its dark.  A very dark brown.  A nice frothy 2 finger head is poured and has nice retention.  Now I was expecting to get wowed by the smell of this beer for some reason.  The mixture that it says on the front of the bottle got me ready for something awesome.  Ale with elderberries aged in bourbon barrels.  Yum sounds fantastic but what I got was very muted.  The Elderberries gave off the biggest smell.  They were sweet.  But everything else like the ripe dark fruit, caramel, and bourbon was lingering there but just small.

Taste was more of the same for me.  Muted.  That doesnt mean it wasnt good though.  The bourbon woody flavor definitely came through more on the taste.  The berries are there and make for a kind of sour and bitter combination.  Under all of that caramel and dark fruits sit on the bottom.  Mouthfeel was really nice.  Thick and smooth.  Silky and sits in your mouth.

25oz bottle, batch 4.  Pours out a nice dark brown hue, medium carbonation.  Aromas are wood, vanilla, cherry, lots of malt.  Palate is fantastic, the cherry and sour levels pound through the entry to mid with the barrel aging finishing it off very smooth.  The levels of vanilla and cocoa are still intact although not as potent as it is fresh, but still a well rounded beer.

750ml bottle shared by the Madison crew.  Deep brown-black, pronounced fruity aroma, adds a deep heavy sourness.  World Class mouthfeel.  Brings to mind De Dolle Reserva.  Hides the alcohol well.  Delicious dark malt tones merge with the fruity sourness.  Perfect balance.  Phenomenal!

I think Deuane brought this one for us to try. Batch 5.

A - Pours dark brown with a small half finger tall off-white head leaving spotty lace down the glass.

S - Smells of elderberrys dominate the nose initially slowly giving way to hints of wet oak, dark fruits, toffee, and some light spice. Not much booze initially but it grows as it warms up.

T - Starts off with a bright berry twang slowly giving way to hints of raisins, toffee, oak, vanilla and warm bourbon. This one has a lot going on at once, leaving you guessing what is going to come through next. Finish is pretty dry, lingering for some time.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth feel initially getting a tad watery toward the end, finish is pretty dry.

O - This one was pretty good. It had plenty of flavor, which was both a good and bad thing. I liked some of the older vintages I have had more but this one was still pretty good.

750ml bottle in a snifter.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of roasted and chocolate malts, elderberries, bourbon, some light hops, and other dark fruits.  Flavor about the same, with lots of berries and bourbon.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good beer, but the berries are a little too much.

750ml bottle (batch 4):  This one pours an opaque, ruby tinged brown color.  There was almost no head and left no lacing.  Nice nose.  There is a heavy, fruity aroma to it:  that must be the elderberries.  Also some faint hints of oak and bourbon.  Interesting taste.  Elderberries, with a bit of sourness.  A fairly full malt bodied in the background.   Hint of bitterness and chocolate in the background.  Excellent!

Pours dark reddish brown with off white head out of 22 oz bottle, aroma has notes of toffee, bourbon, vanilla, spice, dark fruit and red fruit notes in there as well, slight roasted quality.  Taste is nice mix of spices, bourbon, vanilla, toffee, some fruity notes in there as well, nice warming quality but not in a bad way, finished slightly sweet and spicy.  Nicely done.

Bottle (Batch #1, 2007) at the Funky 7. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Great beer overall. Lots of dark fruits, bourbon and wood, some spices, berries, caramel. Medium to full in body with fine to average carbonation. Mild warming finish, toffee, caramel, berries, light vanilla and a very subtle tart note. Excellent beer.

Bottle with Doodler and Co. Thanks everyone! Brown appearance with a brown head. Slightly spicy, tart dark fruity, bourbon aroma, a bit sour aroma. Tart dark berry, bourbon, tangy, caramel malty flavor. Pretty nice beer.

Bottle provided by Ed Roberts. Last bottle of the night. Palate is shot but still pushing through hard. Unique beer with slight hints of fruit and bourbon. Slightly spicy with a nice booze kick to it. Very enjoyable.

75cl traded batch 3 bottle that is probably close to 2 years old. I have no idea what elderberries taste like but as an ardent fan of Monty Python: I love them! Seriosuly though, this is a well made winter warmer with sweet notes and nice vanilla from the barrels. Tasty.

Great aroma... Sweet malt, bourbon, and a slightly sour fruit subtle finish in the nose.  Mouthfeel completely lacks and sense of a 12 monster.  Incredibly balanced... A sour fruit tang in the finish cuts any burn.  Upfront is dusty, and malt  In the mouth the bourbon isnt that present.  Sweet, mild, and delicious.

Draft at rattlea with Brendan, streets, Andrew, and baron. Pours a hazy brown body with creamy brown lacing. Aroma is chocolate and light oak notes. Mouthfeel is thin with notes of chocolate malts, brown sugar, molasses,  and light sweetness.

750 ml bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of berries, bourbon, oak, coconu and toffee. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of berries, bourbon, oak, coconut and toffee with a crisp dry lingering coconut finish.

Bottle. Pours almost black. Tan head. Nose/taste of elderberry, vinous notes, oak, bourbon barrel, Belgian yeast, fig and very sweet dark fruits. Sweet mouth feel with a lingering alcohol finish. Medium body.

Bottle acquired via trade with tgncc...thanks Tom!!!  Dark plum colored pour with a whispy eggshell head.  Aroma of dark fruit, tart cherry skins, elderberry (I guess), oak, vanilla, and caramel.  Flavor is similar with a lot of the sour berry skins finding their way to the palate.  Definitely more puckering than I was expecting but was a fan of it.  The ABV is masterfully hidden.  This one is sneaky!

Pours deep mahogany into a Trappist glass. Mocha head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Dried fruit and earthy chocolate aromas. Medium bodied with sweet caramel and bourbon front to back turning to a warming chocolate covered elderberry finish.

Dark brown-black mahogany color with a thin, medium-fine, light brown head. Aroma consists of caramel and vanilla bourbon barrel notes along with roasted malt and subtle dark fruity notes with cocoa in the background. Dark flavor profile offers some roasted malt astringency with soft chocolate, caramel, and vanilla notes followed by subtle tart blue fruit characteristics. Alcohol flavors are delicately assertive with some oak aspects rounding out the finish. The medium body conveys an excellent malt and alcohol balance which is supplemented by a final fruity lightness.

750 ml bottle into goblet, batch 5.  Pours hazy extremely dark brown color with a dense 1 finger light tan head with good retention that reduces to a small ring of lacing.  A bit of lacing clings to the glass as well.  Aromas of big bourbon, caramel, dark fruits, and molasses; with a bit of booze as well.  Some nice strong aromas here, decent balance as well.  Taste of big dark fruits(elderberries?) with some caramel and light bourbon on the front;  leading to some licorice, molasses, spice, and a bit of slight tartness in the back.  Some lingering sweet notes on the finish for a short bit.  No bitterness noticed, as expected.  Nicely full and smooth body with medium carbonation.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden, not noticing any at all in the taste, but there is a decent warming after the finish.  Great drinkability for 12%, but still a sipper.  Overall, quite a nice Belgian dark ale.  Delicious and smooth drinking.

This poured almost a jet black color with a beige head. Aroma was of bourbon, dark fruits and berries and some toffee and dark sweet malt. Flavor was very malty, lesser bourbon on the taste than the aroma, and some nice berry/ overippend dark fruit in the finish. Nice

Bottle shared thx to Marsiblursi 2011-07-09 Sätila
AR: infected aromas 
AP: pitch black, frouthy/stouthy head
F : tart, elderberries, nutty, warming feeling. Batch no 4

Bomber, courtesy of Marsiblursi. Pours pitch black with a frothy light brown head leaving lace. Aroma is excellent; fresh, sourish, berry, vanilla and alcohol. Flavor is sourish, fruity, berry, malty and bitter. Thin body. Finishes bitter sour.
Bottle, thanks to Marsiblursi. Black beer, brownish head. Elderberry aroma, malty, vinous, whiskey notes, some vanilla. Sourish flavor with berries and fruit. Maybe not the best bottle or batch?
Pitch black, brown head. Aroma is vinous, with notes of chocolate and smoke. Flavor is grapes and berries and oakiness and malt. A bit sour with a sticky finish. Delicious.

750 ml bottle purchased at Whole Foods, Bowery in NYC.  this is a very complex and intriguing beer.  it pours a dark brown / light black with a 1 finger off white / tan head.  subtle bourbon / vanilla nose with the elderberries coming through strong as the beer warms, creating a very pleasing acidic quality.  medium body with aggressive carbonation on the tip of the tongue.  very tart throughout with light oak, vanilla and bourbon notes.  smooth and round with sharp edges.  wonderful finish with the bourbon barrels shining up front with a smooth chocolate undertone followed by more tart berry notes, leaving the mouth a bit dry.

Bottle shared.  This is one of the best beers I have ever had which was a pleasant surprise.  nose is rich dark fruit with very light funk and chocolate and vanilla.  Taste has more components then I can even remember.  The bourbon was perfectly used to accent the beer which had flavors of grapes/elderberries, sour, light malted sweetness, vanilla from the oak, and chocolate.  Amazingly complex beer.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2011 batch 5, This is the most complex beer Ive ever had. Amazing nose, tart, rich malts, dark fruits, hoppiness. Flavor is slightly tart, sweet, berries and bourbon add a rich complexity. There is no tasting this alcohol, amazing beer.

Bottle shared at Damicos Philly Beer Week event.  Pours a deep dark brownish red color with an off-white foam head.  Has an aroma of spicey malts with elderberry.  Its essentially a barleywine with some cherry and elderberry flavor, but then gives you the perfect finish of chocolate notes on the finish.  Loved it.
Bottle.  Dark reddish brown in color with a tan head.  Sweet berry and vanilla aromas.  Tart fruit, muted oak, and vanilla flavors.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours dark with a decent foamy tan head. Sour and fruity nose, with berries and a lactic milkiness and oak. Real funky and sweet taste, the same berry note, chocolate, a bit of coffee, and some malty bourbon sweetness. Oaky light roast malt finish. Smooth and well-carbonated, velvety and full-bodied. Man, I love Captain Lawrence.

I simply could not get enough of this beer.  Incredible!  Pours dark with a tan creamy head.  Smells of elderberries really come through well in the nose.  This also offers coffee, chocolate, and dark fruits.  A very inviting aroma!  Tangy fruits, some good and interesting oak, rather sour, chocolate, coffee, and earth.  The finish is sour and long with hints of coffee.

750 ml bottle, batch 1, courtesy of Paul, thanks a lot! A dark brown to black beer with an average sized, frothy, lacing, mostly diminishing brown head. The aroma is  moderately malty (toasted/roasted grain/bread, caramel, hint of chocolate), with notes of vanilla, elderberries, plums, bourbon, oak and alcohol. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately sour, lightly bitter. Nearly full body, creamy/oily texture, soft carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness, moderately to heavily alcoholic. Really good even out of season, big alcohol bite, not overwhelming, on the contrary well integrated bourbon and oak, complex and enough balanced, with the hint of sourness that works well. This one aged very well,

Bottle. Pours a deep ruby brown with a finger width tan head. Leaves some great lacing down the side of the glass. Sweet berries, liquorice and flowers combine on the nose. Very tarty. Sour cherries and sweet raspberries combine to make a sweet and sour tussle on the palate. Earthy and roasted notes back this one. Interesting beer

UPDATED: APR 23, 2011 Bottle...  Poured deep, dark, ruby with a thin beige head.  Great tart fruit tones. Nice tannins, oak, and cocoa. Caramel, toffee, Cherres, vinous, earthy, dirt and mild booziness.
750 ml bottle.  This is a nice winter beer.  Murky brownish color with a decent head.  The berries come through nice in this one. Very complex.

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a tulip. Appearance is dark brown with a tan head and some light lacing. Nose is tart cherries, berries, oak, light vanilla, and some roast. Fairly complex but I think what I had was too young and hadnt quite integrated yet. The taste is similar with roast and tart fruits. Really nice feel with a bit of tart character and a good body. Drinks well now and this should age supremely.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-04-2010

750ml, just capped, batch no 4.  Nose has some mild Weizenbock notes under the heavy caramel and bourbon/oak/vanilla and alcohol.  Delicious milk chocolate, prunes, brown sugar and molasses.  Really great malt complexity up front, and one of the few big barrel-aged beers Ive had that really, really benefits from the process.  Pours dark mahogany with a rocky light brown head.  Taste is tart and low bittersweetness, dries out, but with sour/tartness remains much longer.  Berries override the mocha, Holunder over the vanilla, with dark cherries taking the lead.  Viscous, dense, creamy mouthfeel, something of a Rodenbach with a woodystrong ale.  Alcohol feels more like 8% than twelve, soft and complex malt with an underlying ripcurrent of roast and spices, lesser grape with raisins and slight must.  Winy, smooth medium-full body.  Just fantastic as a sipper, some very strong sour cherry/berry/fruits up front but undercut by a whole swath of balancers, sort of an upside-down take (with the sour prominent and the roast and barrel as milder accents) and all the more surprising for it.  Even the burps taste lovely.  Boom!

Had this at the Captain Lawrence event at BG in late March. Poured dark brown, aromas of roasted malt, dark fruit, spices, chocolate. Taste started out with a light sweetness but was dry and tart in the middle, more fruit. Very smooth, flavorful, very enjoyable.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de chocolat et de petits fruits avec une pointe de vanille. Apparence: La couleur est noire. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat et de caramel fruité avec une pointe de vanille. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #3579)

The beer is dark brown almost black with nice carbonation.

The aroma is light, lots of spice, and a little oak, prunes, and funk.

The taset is ok, a little sweet to start for me then a lot of spice on the bank end. Not one of my favorite combinations. I think its too sweet overall.
Bottle pours deep brown with a beige head.  Aroma shows notes of brown sugar, bourbon, oak, roasted malt, and berry. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of caramel, vanilla, and vinous fruit.
Sample from bottle.  Dark brown pour, tan head.  Sweet malts, stomach acid sourness, fruit (berries), and caramel.  I am not liking this, a little unpleasant in my opinion.

Poured from a bomber.  Dark color with a decent tan head.  Nose was very good with a slight sour bourbon and malty notes.  Taste was not as enjoyable as it was more tart than I was expecting.  Probably from the elderberries.  The tartness lasted a little long as well.  Alcohol is fairly well hidden.  Not a terrible beer but there are several better options.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 strong boozy aroma with lots of malt, coffee, berries, toffee, vanilla, licorice, and oak. flavor is also interesting and complex but too tart -- maybe a combination of berries and burnt malt, either way the sourness is a bit odd in here. as it warms it smells more and more like super oaky bourbon, which isnt necessary a bad thing. slightly astringent, otherwise a smooth medium body, hot finish.

Poured from a 750ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with decent amount of head.  Smells of chocolate and blueberries...an incredible aroma.  I wish the taste followed better from the aroma, as that chocolate and berry was not there.  There was some amount of tartness in the back end of this.  Disappointing taste after the initial smell.

Poured into a snifter. Batch #4.

4.5 A: Pretty damn close to black in color. Two fingers of super creamy tan head. Pretty good retention considering the ABV and lots of lacing. Very nice here.

4.5 S: Great balance among the components. Bourbon is right in my ideal strength level and complements the beer rather than dominating it. Bourbon lends a boozy, leather, vanilla, and oak component. The strange fruity smell must be the elderberries. Sweet caramel, toffee, plum, and dark cherry.

3.0 T: The taste is a big step down from the appearance and smell. Its really lacking depth at the malt level and the body is too light. Elderberry tartness is strong as is the bourbon components. The caramel and toffee are just about removed. This tastes like a watered down bourbon with elderberries added. Alcohol is extremely well hidden especially given the light body. Disappointing here.

3.0 M: Lightish body. Too damn light and really brought down the taste. Good moderate carbonation and somewhat creamy.

3.0 D: Great aroma, but the taste and mouthfeel simply arent up to par.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-11-2010 22:47:47

Obtained in trade with JoeyBeerBelly, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a solid dark brown/black color with a skimpy tanish head that dissipates quickly. Nose hits you right up front with bourbon, a vinous bourbon. Some figs, prunes, raisins, caramel, and maple in there as well. Taste is wine like. some figs and prunes up front. Followed by the bourbon which brings its vanilla oakey flavors with it. Finish is a bit acidic, almost sour with some yeast trying to poke through at the end. Mouthfeel is robust, but a very dry finish. Carbonation is low. Very complex brew. I enjoyed it very much. Im not sure I tasted any elderberries, but then again I have no idea what they would taste like if I did.

Bottle, from secret Santa, batch # 4. good aroma, sweet, berries, bourbon, raisin, dates. Brownish black color, good head, faded to a ring, minor lace. Tart sweet flavors. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, sweet dry finish. Very interesting. I didnt get a lot of bourbon in either aroma or flavor, just hints. Lots of nuance with flavor. Good stuff.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Smells of berries and bourbon. Taste is tarty with a sour grape and cherry  taste to it. Booze is not overpowering and easy to drink despite the abv. More scents and tastes come out as it warms up. Very interesting and complex. Really good beer to sip and savor.

750 to glass.  Appearance is a dark brown to black with a lacy tan head.  Nose of berries, oak, hints of vanilla.  The taste follows with an immediate tartness that quickly fades leaving a medium bodied strong ale with an almost smoky, tart wood flavor.  Is this really 12%?!   Interesting and great to sip on while the 0 degree weather lingers outside.
Bottle from secret santa!!  Dark brown in color with a long lasting tan colored head.  Berry, oak,  and vanilla in the aroma.  Slight tartness present, too.  Taste follows similarly.  Good stuff.

750 ml bottle shared by beastiefan2k.  Batch 2. Pour is a dark hazed deep brown, touches of ruby, and a smallish light tan head. Aroma is bourbon oak wood up front, followed close behind by berry (I assume this is Elderberry), and mild vanilla sweetness. Taste is the nose, with bourbon being the main initial story, and the berry moving forward some from the nose. Finishes pretty hot with bourbon.  Behind the initial favor profile is a pleasant Belgian yeast.  Palate is full to medium bodied, lowish carbonation. Finishes with some heat.  Nice sipper.  Thanks for opening this one up, Eugene!

Batch 001= received in a trade awhile ago.

A-Body is an opaque dark brown hue. Pours with a 1/2 finger creamy off-white head-has good rentention the whole way through but little lacing left behind in the glass.

S-Elderberry, raisin, over-ripe plum, cinnamon sugar, nose is very dark- a hint of bourbon as well.

T- Cinnamon sugar is the most dominant upfront-a slight dried (dark) fruitiness comes through as well. Flavor is sweet and overripened-very similar to an RIS that focuses on dark fruit. Hints of anise and licorice are also noticable in the flavor. A slight alcohol heat lingers on the palate.

M- Medium-tingly carbonation with a quite thick heavy weight body.

D- This is much like an IRS that overemphasizes the dark fruity flavors. Overripened fruit everywhere- its thick, heavy, and wintery as well. What I do enjoy about it is the extra flavor of cinnamon sugar. Decent overall-but probably my least favorite of the captain lawrence lineup so far.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-28-2010 03:33:50

750mL bottle, Batch 1.. and my first good beer of the new year!  Poured cola brown (or a little deeper) with just a ring of loose tan bubbles sticking around for head.  The aroma picked up warm molasses, blended chocolates, and elderberry meat that was complemented very well by sweet bourbon, oak, and dried vanilla bean.. deep, malty, and seductive.  The flavor opened with alcohol-amplified tangy oak, bourbon, and berry skins..  berry sweetness and molasses did most of the work on the middle, with brighter oak, slightly metallic bourbon, and some oxidation around.. finished with a nice blend of sweet and tangy, with the alcohol really warming up the belly.  Heavier-bodied and slick on the palate due to low carbonation.. a little bit too sweet, but still a very good brew.

750ml. Dark murky brown, thin head. Berry vanilla oak nose, smooth in mouth, light tangy almost funky finish (from the berries), fruity esters, light bourbon oak, vanilla, nice and inviting, good warmer,

verticle tasted at Joes goodbye party:
batch 1: light fruity, berries and oak. dark body, a touch of acidity, dark licorice, brown sugar milky mouthfeel.
batch 2: less bitter than batch one. touch of skink from the age, brown sugar and molasses
batch 3: more sour dark fruits, not as much chocolate
batch 4  hazy brown pour, berries and oak. sweet malts and tart notes.
Dark muddy brown; thin head. Bourbony aroma. Big and boozy, lots of bourbon, and a sour note that may be the elderberry.

Pour from the bottle of Batch #4 thanks to Kan from chilly Chicago. Dark brown purple hue with a slight off white top. Aromas of grape and berries, sweet malt and oak. Medium bodied brew and very smooth. Flavors are very good and complex. Fruity, yeasty, boozy, and toasty. Finish is on the drier side. Mild funky sourness.  Interesting, different, and good.

Bottle from Glouglouburp.   Thanks Dany!  Batch 2.  Time to see what this beer is all about on a chilly evening.  Pours a dark brown color with some deep amber and a good sized tan head develops.  This looks rather dark once in the glass.  Kind of like a cola color.  A thin foam maintains on top for a little bit of lacing.  Fruity aroma; can pick up the elderberries.  Caramel and bourbon follow with vanilla and oak.  Smells good.  Rich flavors include a good dose of caramel with strong but refined bourbon notes.  The berries show rather strong as well and provide a funky tartness in the finish.  While there is a bit of a funky element here its nothing like the Smoke From The Oak series.  Once I get past those stronger flavors there are some nice lingering chocolate notes.  At first I thought there might be one too many dominant flavors here but really this is quite good.  Its warming without being alcoholic and is certainly an interesting and complex brew.

Served from a 750 mL bottle thanks to Nolan. Batch 4. The appearance is a deep berry fruit juice hue. No real head on this brew. The aromas are very berry forward with a slightly sour barrel note. The flavors are yeasty at first, loads of good berries, fruity bourbon, light in intensity sour notes. Some stem like flavors. The mouth is medium to full bodied, more juice like in texture. Some nice different flavors.Very enjoyable.
It smells and tastes to me like a barleywine. It has the sweet resin malt flavors and medium to thick body. It pours dark chestnut with a creamy small tan head.
privileged to taste some batch 1 at the brewery.  murky dark brown color. sweet, and complex with berry and oak flavors.  reminded me of angels share. i would love to try some fresh.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a 1 finger head that settles down to form a nice collared medium bubbled light tan head. Swirling causes the head to form a nice tan coaster. The aroma is somewhat odd with chocolate notes mixed with a sweet/tart berry note. Hmm, the taste is rather different with an almost sweet tart taste to it, must be the elderberries. So far I dont get too much bourbon barrel in either the nose or the taste. Medium mouthfeel. Nice left on the glass as I drink this down. A very interesting beer even as it warms. Tartness somewhat bites at the tongue followed by some grape like sweetness and some dark chocolate notes. Finishes with a slight alocohol warming sensation. Different, I wish it had more chocolate flavors and less elderberry tartness.
Batch 4.  Dark brown-red, beige cover.  Aroma is fruity, vanilla, roasty, bourbon.  Taste is more sweet vanilla, some bourbon, a lot of chocolate.

Black, no head. Nice aroma - red wine, raisin and prune. Nice favor, too - smoky, a little bit of pine, then some fruity, tart notes. Hints of chocolate, as well. Sampled at 2010 pre-Brewers Jam tasting.

A Mes rate. Bottle at the Kernel, very kindly supplied by Thomas.Deep dark ruby coloured with a lasting creamy beige head. Wow, well, I wasnt expecting this. It seems a little oxidised to me but the fruit and sourness are quite an experience. Plenty of dried fruit and molasses and raisins and stuff. The Elderflower is there but its so delicate the more assertive elements are making it struggle to break through. The bourbon is thankfully reasonably restrained and its all the better for it. Excellent barrel notes and a really interesting sweet and sour character. Maybe just a little too much on the sweet side for what it is. Really good tarty finish rounds every thing off really nicely. Good one.

Bottle; thanks to the generosity of Puzzl. Andy, you rule mate! All-round rating at Kernel Brewery.

Very very delicate oak aged bourbon aroma; quite faint,  bourbon, chocolate, grainy texture and aroma, lots of amazing sourness ala rodenbach, wild berries, really excellently balanced, not at all aggressive, very very drinkable, soothing alcohol. A really great winter ale. Another winner from Captain Lawrence. Thoroughly enjoyed in London rain.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty fruity spicy elderberry aroma. Sweetish fruity spicy elderberry flavor with some weak sour hints. Has a slightly roasted malty spicy elderberry finish with some weak sour hints.

Very nice aroma: elderberry pie, hints of vanilla.  Flavor has a medium light tartness from the fruit and is surprisingly dry - I was expecting a good measure of sweetness along with the fruitiness but its quite lightly sweet.  Intense berry flavor with a good measure of bitterness on the finish.  The barrel aging is rather subtle too.

Courtesy of Artusory. Dark brown, mahogany edges to light, tan head. Aroma has dark fruits up front, mostly grape, bourbon takes over as it awarms. Flavor has big malt character, chocolate, bourbon, light buttery character, faint nuts/pecan. Some residuel sweetness. Carbonation lacks a bit.

Well for rating #700 I finally got a chance to try a brewery that I cant get around here.  Ooooo Im so excited!   So lets do this.  Pours a really dark brown color with a nice and dark head.  I can already smell berries and Im not even close to sniffing yet.  Aroma is of berries, malts, oak, coconut, and licorice.  Flavor is a little boozy with malts, oak, berries, raisins, and coconut.  A little bit of coffee seems to also be present in the back end.  Leaves a raisin malt finish.  Even though this is a winter brew, Im happy to finally have one from Captain Lawrence.

Bottle. Dark brown pour, plenty of carbonation and an aroma of dark berries and bourbon.  Flavor is a lot of sweet malt, boozy red grapes, some spice and finished bourbony/boozy. Well balanced and solid beer, would definitely drop $15 for another bottle.

750ml bottle shared at the old mans birthday bash 
Appearance: Pours black with a small tan head leaving some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, vanilla and chocolate 
Taste: Dark malts, woody and sour fruits in the finish 
OK, the different favors dont mesh good together.

Another awesome bottle at the July tasting for Erics birthday. Pours a nice black color with a small white head. The aroma is earthy cocoa, chocolate and light bourbon. The flavor has all of that, more pronounced bourbon, but also a distinct and odd sourness. Dry and dusty, but the woody and sour flavors are not fitting in. Still, a good brew.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Batch #4 

Pours a deep, darker cola brown that verges on a dense look, with a decent finger of dark tan foamy head that dissipates pretty quickly. 

The aroma is very vinous at first (as they seemed to think on the label as well), lightly sweet maltiness; grapes; a touch of toffee; a very faint bourbony note in the nose, but dont catch any alcohol. The flavor definitely shows the bourbon and mirrors the vinous nature of the nose. A bit tangy in the finish as well as a hint of sweetness. Really nice stuff all around. The bourbon aftertaste on the palate really makes this stand out in a tasty and interesting way. Very warming, and a medium MF with fairly soft carbonation. Great sipping brew, delicious.

Courtesy of Mark, at Mr. Beerys in Sarasota, FL. I couldnt place what the aroma consists of (but was happy that the bourbon barrels didnt make it too boozy).  Dark in appearance with a sweet and bitter flavor.  I am not familiar with elderberries, but Im assuming that some of the flavor that I cant figure out were from them. Overall, a good beer.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with a pin stripe of white head.

Aroma: Grandmas house (musty shag carpet and old books), bourbon and chocolate.

Taste: Bourbon, wood, elderberry, vanilla and leather.

Mouthfeel: Full with modest carbonation.

Overall:  I wasnt hip on this beer, but became infinitely better as it came to room temperature. Complex, with flavors Im not used to.
Not that impressed, maybe this just isnt my thing. Sweet/sour cherry from the nose all the way through the finish.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Aroma has a lot of bourbon and oak notes, a good amount of fruit sweetness along with some mild roasted hints. Flavor starts with a nice sweet and fruity bourbon combination with a good amount of vanilla and wood hints coming up at the end. The elderberry tartness begins to emerge at this point and give way to a very lightly roasted finish. No idea it was 12%.

Big thanks to Sarah for sharing this at our tasting.  Batch 1.

A-pours a dark brown, almost black liquid with a ton of tight creamy tan head.

S-a good bit of roasted malts, chocolate, touch of roasted coffee.  there is a hint of oak and bourbon underneath.  The back has a touch of sweetness with what I am assuming are the elderberries followed by some light booziness in the back.

T-lots of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, brown sugar, touch of slightly burnt coffee.  boozy in the back with a light sweetness of berries and plums.

M-very smooth and creamy on the palate, lighter full body with a good carbonation and crisp finish that is quite dry.

D-this is a pretty drinkable beer, very much like a stout with a good sweetness to it that isnt like the big malty sweetness of most imperial stouts.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2010 Bottle via rlmartin, batch 4.  Pours to a swamp of brown almost-sludge...bright burgundy, maybe even purple highlights near the glass edge.   Head atops a tan color, atmospheric swirls in the center, some concentration around the sides.  Nose is what I like..deep, somewhat sweet tartness from the elderberries, evident bourbon with soft vanilla edges, with cakey chocolate malt nose riding behind.  Somewhat tart, tannic, and vinous intro to flavors carrying along with it a bit of non-descript malt profile with maybe hints of chocolate and very slight whispers of charred wood.  Alcohol felt in the warmth but not tasted.  Grapey, vinous finish.  The mouthfeel has definite bourbon barrel influences as its rather soft, though its nicely accented by the delicate tartness of the fruit that combines with the oak influence to sour things up a little bit.  I think it could use with a more aggressive malt structure though...or something a little deeper, more chocolate, a heavier accent on the smoke maybe, even some more malt sweetness...but thats just nitpicking or trying to compare it to cuvee de tomme or something, which it isnt though it does remind me of cuvee a little bit.  In any event, its quite nice, regardless.

750mL. Pours an opaque muddy brown that completely light blocking. One finger tan head has excellent retention and webby lacing. Aroma is sour cherries, some bourbon and vanilla that dont quite mix in perfectly with the tart cherries- its almost like a strawberry milkshake or strawberry yogurt in the nose. As it warms the nose is more like fresh cherry pie. Taste is a bit metallic, some lactic sourness, sort of a weird base beer that has some off medicinal qualities and is fairly thin-bodied. Not sure if the lactic infection is good for this beer. 12% is amazingly hidden regardless.

Bottle thanks to mikey711. Pours a hazy dark brown with  as strong red hue and a light brown head that laces a bit. Aroma has notes of dark fruits with underlying tartness, bourbon and caramel. Flavor begins with sweet dark fruits and a hint of caramel, but the finish has a hint of wine, as well as a hint of coffee.

This review is for batch 1.

Pours a very dark purplish plum color that is almost brown with a two finger coffee colored head with decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting cap. Sporadic chunks of lacing left behind.

Roasted malty aroma with lots of silky chocolate, dark fruit, especially dark berries, oak and bourbon. There is also some slight peppery spice present in the nose accompanying the seet berry and roasted malt character.

Fuller end of medium body with a nice viscous malty mouthfell that lasts throughout into a slightly dry finish. Nice balance of subtle bourbon, earthy oak, sweet dark fruit, silky chocolate and dark roasted malt. Sweetness from the dark berries. which results in a slightly vinous presence with hints of grape, blackberry and blueberry. Slightly smokey with some roasted coffee character that balances out he sweetness and bourbon. The barrel aging adds some vanilla oak character which adds a nice complexity to this unique beer. Very well balanced and dangerously drinkable.

big thanks to exiled for sharing this batch 4 bottle.  poured black with a cream head.  nose is bourbon, vanilla, alcohol, and a great sweetness to it.  nice on he vanilla, sweet vanilla, cherries, bourbon, chocolate, and a nice finish with a slight sourness.

Thanks to exiled for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is a mix of roasted malt and tart cherries. The flavor is a lot of tart cherries along with bourbon, roasted malt, oak and vanilla. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Not sure what I was expecting, but this was completely different  but in a very good way.

Batch 2 bottle from hopdog.  Got another more recent batch from j12601.  Never had this "fresh"  but this was great with 2.5 years on it.  Shared on DLD 2010 eve.   Awesome layers of  tart cherry skins,  berries, bourbon, vanilla, and plums.   Really liked this and excited to try it again.

750 ml bottle shared by shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a very dark brown, opaque, with a nice big beige head.  Aroma of currants, bourbon, vanilla, oak, dark fruits (tart cherries, blackberries, plums, and figs).  Maybe elderberries are in there as well or Im mistaking them for other berry fruits; I honestly had never heard of them before this.  The flavor is nicely balanced between the barrel notes, the fruit, and the alcohol.  Just a super cool, interesting beer and an unexpected treat during an epic drinking session.
(750ml bottle thanks to Exiled) clear brown pour with creamy head and excellent lacing. Nose of berries, tart fruits, cream. Taste of tart fruit, dates, raisins, with a creamy and oily finish. Nice!

batch 3: held on to for just under a year and a half .. . Pours a murky dark brown, lacing is satisfactory .. . what style is this? muddled .. .Its just Bernie! .. was really hoping for more fruit/bourbon in this one.. . but a good brew, just surprised it wasnt bigger/more intricate .. . My old man worked hard. All they did was give him more work..

courtesy of degarth at the Whole Foods / CCB Cask Event.
pours dark brown, tan head.
aroma and flavors of barrel, hints of vanilla, dark malts and sugar, hints of berries with a light chocolate mouthfeel, bourbon palate with a nice lingering warming boozy and barrel palate though not overpowering the whole experience.

Another tasty treat by Captain Lawrence.

Opaque chocolate colored with dense brown head.  Aroma is of malted chocolate milk balls with sweet marshmallow, and a hint of oak.  Taste is unexpectedly very tart, tangy lactic character, less prominent roast, and beautiful bourbon character beneath it all.  If this isnt what its supposed to taste like (the elderberries and whatnot), it seems the barrels could stand some sanitization $11/22oz

Thanks to Drinkndrive for hooking this one up.  Pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is big fruit and malt: berries, bourbon, wood, booze, malt, and some vanilla. The flavor is similar with lots of malt, berry, bourbon, and complexity.  Medium to full bodied and very enjoyable sipping beer.
Bottle at CCB, back room, courtesy of Joey.  Late in the evening, my taste buds were spinning by then.  Lots of scotch, chocolate and butterscotch flavors, candy aromas, great body.  Top notch.

Wow. Couleur brune foncée avec reflets rougeatre. Aromes de vanille et de boisé avec une petite touche de fumée. Ronde en bouche, elle offre de délicieuses saveurs de vanille, de bois, de fumée et dalcool. Tres bien balancée pour une biere a 12%.

Aroma: Definately a fruity almost Vinous nose...a little caramel malt...and of course a mild oaky bourbon nose.
Appearence:  Minimal head pured from bottle into several snifters...poured a clear brownish red...
Taste: Wow a beer that thinks it is a wine is the best way to describe this taste...somehow the bourbon and the elderberries mix for this fruity sensation similar to wine...a little sweet and sour like a wine with mild tannins.
Palate: Medium body light carbonation but a quick finish

Overall: I truly enjoyed this beer.  It is not like any other beer i have tried...but my wife being a wine lover really enjoyed this one as well.

Bottled (thanks Degarth!). Deep ruby red colour, small brown head. Aroma is fruity and wooden along with some alcohol and some slight raisins. Flavour  is raisins, alcohol, wooden, and quite hoppy. Quite much sweet and very strong wooden notes.

Bottled 0,66ltr (batch #3)
Dark black, opaque color, small tan head. Lots of vanilla and oak in the nose. Medium-bodied. Dark malts, some sourness, vanilla and coffee. A bit too sticky and harsh to be an excellent. Warming alcohol in the aftertaste.

Pours brown with a very dense tan head. The aroma is rich with cherries, berries, chocolate, bourbon, caramel, vanilla, and wood. Big time bourbon barrel presence. The flavor is very tart and fruity with lots of sour berry flavor melding nicely with the powerful bourbon notes. Chocolaty malts in there too. Super velvety mouthfeel and very thick and smooth. Unique beer, and very tasty.

Dark brown/black pour, 
aroma is intense dark malt, bourbon, tart blackberry, elderberry, some roast and milk chocolate, Huge Wood.  vanilla bourbon.  Flavor is bourbon, vanilla, Oak barrel.  great fruitiness, blackberry, elderberry, currant.

Thanks jblauvs! Straight black pour with a ridiculously vivacious beige head. The aroma is immediately pervasive in the room. Elderberry and  tart currant are huge- caramel, molasses, and milk chocolate follow. Oak tannins and vanilla bourbon are noticeable but never overbearing. The flavor is vanilla bourbon to the max- the fruit character gives way to woody barrel and mild lactic sugars. The sweetness is huge and welcomed. The palate is rich and very thick. The mouth feel is sticky and smacking. Goddamn.

Again, thanks to jblauvs. Gorgeous pour, near black with a pretty and frothy beige head. Aroma holds lots of currant notes which is presumably elderberry (cant say Ive ever encountered an elderberry), awesome bourbon quality, wood, alcohol, and some tartness to the fruit- really interesting, and I definitely dig it. Flavor is absolutely full of bourbon barrel, still with some nice fruit, vanilla, and some lactic sugar. Palate is pretty full-bodied, with some definite booze character, but still quite drinkable. Really nice brew on the whole.

A:  Pours a dark brown with red highlights.  Medium sized tan head.

S:  Caramel, nutty toffee, oak, and vanilla.

T:  Malty goodness.  Chocolate, light coffee, cherries, sweet candy malts and bold oak and vanilla.

M:  Medium in body, smooth.

D:  Pretty good.  A solid beer for sure.

Bottle, batch number 4 from The Ginger Man. Wonderful beer, wish it was local. Incredibly drinkable for how big it is, with the dark fruit and berries really standing out, giving it an almost vinous quality. Finishes with a touch of sourness, which adds to the complexity and enjoyment of this fine brew.
Dark brown almost black with tan head and lace. Abv, roasted malt, and coffee on the nose. Sweet mediciny malt and light coffee. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

Bottle. Pours slightly deep brown, slightly murky, topped with a medium khaki head. Aroma is bourbon-forward, with plenty of oak, chocolate, vanilla up front, with liquorice, molasses, and some spice in the background. Flavor is a bit different than the aroma, with oak, cocoa, dark fruit, and vanilla. Oak and earth overtake the other flavors and stick around for a long finish. Body is thinner than expected. Pretty decent, but I expected more based on the aroma.
Complex nose and palate. Hints of artificial strawberry, cherry pie, and other fruits. Almost too complex, and has the taste of sugar.

2010-02-28, bottle, courtesy of Papsø, 7-4-7-3-14=35The color is very dark, the head is medium-sized. Mild aroma of caramel and red wine. Good body strength, sweetish caramel flavor, with red wine, and finally some liquorice; the final is slightly salty. Tonight it seems a bit chaotic: I cant appreciate the wine with the liquorice with the caramel.2009-10-17, draught at New Beers Distributors, New York, 8-5-8-4-17=42Black color; creamy head. Wonderful vanilla oak aroma, alcohol, whisky. Good body strength, chocolate and caramel flavor, vanilla oak, and a light sourness from the fruits that fits together very well. The alcohol is clearly perceived. There is some liquorice in the end (and I dont fancy that too much). Vibrating, but its difficult to drink too much of it.

Bottle at the 10th Richmond RateBeer Gathering courtesy of Puzzl on 01/16/2010. Batch #2. Clear deep amber body with ruby highlights and a small creamy tan head. Sweet molasses, caramel and light spice aroma with a touch of alcohol. Sweet alcohol, molasses, rum soaked fruit, light chocolate and roasted malt flavor with a touch of alcohol. Medium full body with moderately high carbonation.

Bottle [750ml] shared w/ friends at the 2nd Annual Buffalo Cask Festival -- c/o rudolf. Batch #2. Pours a very dark brown with a small diminishing creamy tan head. Nice aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, oak, vanilla and bourbon -- all well balanced. Flavour of rich roasted malt and dark fruit along with vanilla, oak, bourbon and some alcohol. Dry finish. Medium bodied. A fantastic beer, I loved it!

Pours deep brown, thin head from the 22oz. bottle: Aroma of oaked wood, sweet malts, brown sugar, unsweetened cocoa, and dark caramel. Unsweetened cocoa flavors take over the palate though you can taste traces of the oak. Not much body, however theres almost no trace of alcohol. Drinkability: Balanced session ale. Rebuy: Yes. #272 on 06022010, DG.

brown, small brown head.
aroma is swet, roasted grains, booe,  faint licorice, hops.
flavor is roasted graims , licorice, faitn sourish, wood, super well blended, good use of wood.

Botella, thanks a lot for sharing Plovmand.! Deep dark brown colour. Pleasant deep dark malty oak alco vanilla dark fruity aroma, mild tartness. Good mouthfeel. Sweet dark malty vanilla oaky dark fruity bit spiced flavour with a mild tartness in the finish.

Rating #1900. Thanks daknole for providing. Dark brown body with a medium creamy tan head. Lots of oak, caramel, dried fruit and brown sugar in aroma. I sense a slight bretty note with notes of light spices and berries. Very complex. The flavour is dark roasted malts, vanilla, oak, berries, prune, raisins, bourbon, warming alcohol and rich toasted caramel. Ends up dark fruity and light alcoholic.

Bottle. Poured a deep brown with red tint and a creamy beige head. Aroma of cocoa, hops, bourbon, and blueberries. The nose is a bit overdone with a burnt quality to it. The flavor profile includes cocoa, caramel, licorice, and blueberries. There is an early porter/dark ale quality that is overtaken by a tangy, tart berry stickiness in the finish. Its almost a stout-sour hybrid without the potentially overwhelming qualities of either. I dont know how many times I commented "This is f****** weird," as I drank this, but I enjoyed it more and more as it warmed and as I got used to it. Id venture this way again, especially since I know what to expect now.
Batch # 4 bomber. Dark frothy thick pour with a tan head that lasts. Roasted barley berries smokey chocolate notes. Very refreshing!

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 Bottle shared after the Bruery Reserve Society Initiation.  Pours very dark brown with a small tan head and a little lacing.  Aroma is roasty and sour, with funk, dark fruit, and vanilla.  Flavor is also roasty and really tart, surprisingly.  Some nice complexity in there - some sweet caramel malt pokes through the tartness, and there are vinous notes, oak, vanilla, and coffee flavors in there.  12% ABV?  No way!  This does not have the syrupiness or the booziness that Id expect from a winter warmer of that strength.  Body is medium-full and fairly dry and acidic.  Got to give it a bump up on the palate for achieving that effect, since it seems like it would be tough to accomplish in a beer like this.  Overall, this is good despite the oddities to it.
EDIT: Had this again 2/21/2010.  Crazy beer that seems to have a lot of bottle-to-bottle variation.  This time it wasnt nearly as tart, but was very funky on the aroma, like feet.  Despite the inconsistency, I like this beer.

Bottled sample(batch 2) via oakbluff. Near black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas are of sour dark berries, funk, and strong malts. Quite boozy in the mouth, with some berry sweetness, black chocolate, and bourbon on the back end. Theres a strange drying quality that competes with the berry sweentess on the palate. A confusing beer to say the least. Tough to drink, unfortunately.

750ml bottle courtesy of Glouglouburp -batch 2.  Been waiting a while to crack this baby. Pours a very murky dark ebony with minimal head. Nose- slightly sour fruit, earthy, boozy.  Body is on the thin side, dark fruit and boozy hot.  This beer is going in 20 different directions, some are the wrong way on a one way. Oxidation starting to creep in, worsening the thinness of body and taste.
Pours a nice dark brown. It has a sweet vanilla smell with a slightly creamy head. Taste is oak, vanilla, toffee, coffee and caramel. It is excellent and well worth the wait. I tasted a 2008 vintage.

Very deep brown, slight head.  Aroma is chocolate and wood, oak is evident.  Some chocolate flavors dominate.  Really the main flavor is cocoa, not much else.  A bit of woodsiness at the end as well.  Good, but not great.

Bottle from Maniacs Richmond Tenth Gathering.  Pours a very dark brown with ring of tan head.  Nose is like a cabernet savignon and chocolate.  Flavor is sweet, plum, bourbon, yogurt, anise.  grapes, vinous.  Great syrupy, silky body.  Very good.

Bottle thanks to NYbeer.  Pour is very dark brown with a light reddish tinge and a thin tan head that dissipates to a few random lilly-pad-like patches.  Aroma is rich caramel malt, light vanilla-bourbon notes, light wood, faint fruitiness, and a light smokiness.  Flavor is smooth caramel malt with a light bourbon and smoke background.  Finish is light roasted malt, light fruity sweetness and some leather and tobacco.  It is earthy, rich, and smooth.  The body is not quite as heavy as I was expecting, but it hides 12% well.  Only a light alcohol twinge.  I think its good.

Deep dark brown color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of elderberries predominates with hints of caramel, toffee, and a bit of bourbon.  Flavor is malty with elderberry, caramel, and some bourbon flavor.  Slightly unusual and easy to drink.

Going off sparse notes here, but the general point is not lost.  Pours a deep cloudy brown with thin tan head, little lacing.  Aroma strong of oak, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, and dark and tart fruits.  Taste threw me for a loop because it just didnt seem to come together correctly with such a sourness present.  Just too much going on and flavors that arent meant to be together IMO.

I dont like the cold. I like even less the freezing horrid storms that Old Man Winter brings; the NorEaster. Once you know one, you love them no more, the frosty romanticism frozen solid in the pit of your stomach as fear, loathing, and gloom looms heavy upon your soul. Sunny Florida, replete with sandy beaches, skin-replenishing humidity, tiki bars, and surf is where life is truly at. Dont agree with me? I knew there was something wrong with you, but its ok. There is always hope. Whether they be honest fans of the crotchety ol NorEaster or just inserting a little tongue-in-cheek humor, Captain Lawrence Brewing out of Pleasantville, NY offers a Winter Warmer aptly named NorEaster. Maybe its a ward to warn off the real deal? Either way, it is hopefully far more enjoyable and much less dangerous than his bigger and badder brother.


His depths are stormy browns and blacks, swirling beneath patches of khaki clouds while a thick ring lingers. As the skies prepare to open up and rain hell and high water upon winters hapless denizens, the NorEaster Winter Warmer releases its own storm of candied fruit ala fruitcake, licorice root, fig, and dates, pits included of course. The pits offer a deep earthy nuttiness while alcohol offers an eye-opening slap right at the end. Im awake; really I am. The abrupt hit of alcohol heat also offers a compromise of sweet warmth which blends with a gruit of brown spices and wood. Certainly more inviting than his blustery brother, I dive deep in to the approaching storm and find a welcoming embrace of brown spices, figs, dates, and dry wood steeped in alcohol warmth while a pervading sweetness prevents her palate from completely poaching mine. Each quaff finishes with an assertive dryness, almost like a dry rub of brown spices, wood, and pits atop my tongue. The dark fruits are unfortunately much less prominent in the palate than they were in the nose, though there is a gentle undercurrent of dry European chocolates that were not present in the nose but are present in his palate. Are those red apples sprinkled with cinnamon? Before I have a chance to discern, they are gone. A few more quaffs, and there is nothing more to find. The NorEaster Winter Warmer from Captain Lawrence Brewing has blown through, blustered about, and then fizzled away.


Not too bad, but nothing ground-breaking or inspiring. Id certainly quaff another, but in the world of winter brews, he is like many of his fellow brothers and sisters of the winter storm.

Thanks Ucusty!  After I pop the cap off, the beer starts to foam up like a gusher in slow motion.  Pours dark brown with a good sized tan head.  Aroma might be soured or infected and Im not sure how intentional that is.  Anyway, theres a strong berry presence, cinnamon, raisin, clove, and maybe some brett or other "bug."  Tastes more malty with caramel, wood, vanilla, berries, fruity funk, toast, and earth.  Finishes with a big wood and roast presence, almost stout-like in nature with plenty of hops, coffee, caramel, and light bourbon.  Great mouthfeel, the carbonation is effortless, body is thick, full, and unsyrupy.  Very nice, but I wonder if its exactly as the brewer intended...

Interesting idea with a lot going on.  Vanilla and dark malts and bourbon in the nose and in the flavor, with some sweetness and some sourness.  Off putting notes of alcohol (at 12% not exactly a surprise) and vanilla again from the barrels, and elderberries (I dont think I would do that again!) and bubble gum.  Great concept, but it just doesnt work for me.

2009 Bottle Batch 4 - Thanks eyedrinkale! - Pours a lively deep brown with a small lt tan head...aroma is dangerously similar to their SFTO bottles, of which all the ones Ive tried have been moderately to extremely fucked, so this should be interesting...tart and tannic, oaky phenols and dk berries, bourbon and some vanilla...flavour is a nice surprise as I can tell that it hasnt been accidently soured, dark berry fruit and skin, cherry and some light chocolate...subtle bourbon, with more oak barrel taste over the actual bourbon...finish is lightly spiced with some lingering tart berry in the back of the throat...better as it opens and warms for sure...
Brown body, tan head. Aroma is sweet berry and honey. Taste is sweet and tart with yeast. Has some bitterness in the finish and alcohol.

Bottle from Batch 4.  Fruity malt aroma, tangy and vinous, with a bit of alcohol.  Very dark pour.  Taste is a heavy fruit and hop mix - sour berries, yeast, lots of citrus flavor, and a bit of smoke.  The finish has a strong chocolate presence, and the high ABV does not really show its face.  I didnt fall in love with this stuff, but it certainly is a very interesting ale.

Draft. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Light roasty and sweet dark fruity aroma. The flavor... wow, where to start. Berry like sweetness, close to blackberry, with some toffee and caramel like sweetness as well. Bourbon notes dont dominate, but round out the flavor, with some toasty malty notes lingering underneath. Really good.

Batch 3 750 mL bottle from New Beer Distributors in Manhattan, brought back to me by a friend. Pours a very dark bronze-tinged brown color with a medium tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. The aroma is strong bourbon, oak, vanilla and elderberry, along with some notes of maple, cherries, citrus and something very faintly vegetal. Taste is tart elderberry notes, along with chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, oak, citrus. Slight alcohol warmth. Full bodied.

Drove over to captain lawrence today and picked this up prior to first blizzard of 2009.  Pours dark and murky, smells of bourbon. leather, and slightly off.  tastes great of dried fruit, slight vanilla, and something else i cant place.  very diifferent brew than i normally drink but very enjoyable

750ml bottle.  Aroma is full of bourbon, dark fruits, alcohol, dark, toasty malts, flowers, red grape, dark brown sugar, cherry, faint vanilla, and what must be elderberry, along with faint leather and wine.  Deep brown color with a faint purplish tinge and a very fine head.  flavor is likewise sweet and full of bourbon character, fruity with hints of wood, more dark berry, vanilla and licorice.  Alcohol presence is substantial.  Slick, warming mouthfeel, smooth, with a massive body.  Really quite nice, flavorful and huge.

Bottle - thanks Secret Santa! - shared @ the 2nd annual Buffalo cask festival. Very dark brown, tan head.  Nose is light bourbon, vanilla, roasty malt, alcohol, cherries and dried fruits.  Flavor is honey, rich malts, caramel, whiskey.  The finish gets drier as it goes on - I guess from some tannins.  Warming & nice.

750ml. Pours dark murky brown with tan head. Aroma is bourbon, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate and some berries. Flavor was strong with bourbon, vanilla, wood, roasted malts, chocolate, and elderberries. Finishes boozy with bourbon. Medium mouthfeel. Can really taste the barrel with this one. Nice winter warmer but glad I shared it with some friends as I would of had trouble taking on the whole 750 by myself.

bottle shared by Rudolf. Darker pour, aromas of dried fruits, light bourbon. Richer darker malts. Light booze is well hidden. extremely well balnced. dried fruitiness, malty richness. Great beer. Thanks to rudy for this gem

750 ml from LilBeerDoctor shared with friends. Thanks, Margaret! Pours a deep dark ruby brown, not opaque but fairly murky, a small offwhite head that dies to a sketchy film, laces ok. Aromas are a nice smaller whiff of bourbon, oak and vanilla with a light booziness, toasty caramel malts with a touch elderberry, vanilla, and chocolate. A light feel of dark fruit, toasty, light bitterness. Initial is surprisingly fruity, dark fruits and bourbon barrel comes in behind, lighter with vanilla and solid booziness, a touch of Belgian yeast, a bit of elderberry, a fuller bodied beer, heavier side of medium but not quite syrupy thickness. This is quite fruity, with bourbon and Belgian yeast striking an interesting balance, meshing with some sweeter caramel and biscuity malts, a touch of toast, finish is lightly bitter, fruity, and boozy with a good wet wood element.

Bouteille de 750 ml, au Bières et Bouffe. Arômes de malt très complexes (caramel brûlé, chocolat, pruneaux). Robe brune foncée, pas de mousse et effervescence faible. Très ronde en bouche, le malt généreux et sucré (caramel, mélasse, chocolat) est accompagné dune touche fruitée et légèrement boisée. Très riche et décadente, lalcool est peu apparent pour une bière aussi forte. Excellent !
Bottle at a tasting. Nose is : sweet raisins, fruits, molasses, hops. some roasted malt also. Taste is sweet red fruits with some hops. Finish is a bit bitter and roasty. Warm feeling.

7th September 2008. Opaque black beer. Slightly creamy, very distinct fruit from the elderberries. Lots of woody tones with the bourbon in the background. A hint of toasty malt in the finish. Not bitter but slighty dry. Very complex beer.

Lucky enough to get to try a bottle of this recently. Colour... medium brown with no head. Nose... good God theres a whole lot of elderberry there! Palate... sweet at the front of the palate with some light CO2 an then more of the elderberries which echo on the finish!

Bottle on October 30, 2009. Bourbon barrelsClear dark brown color, light brown head. Acidic, wood, alcohol scent. Acidic, sweet, slaty taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Chocolate and wood aftertaste.

1/2 growler from New Beer Distributers in NYC, produces large bubbles in a one finger head that fades quickly leaving big bubbles ringing the glass, and abundant lacing. Killer aroma of bourbon, cherries, candied sour apple. Slightly dry taste of oak, with flavors of mellon, cherries, and other berries. Verges on being a sour style beer. Throat puckering dry aftertaste and definite wood on the palate. The alcohol stays hidden until you burp it. Man, Im partial to these bourbon barrel aged beers.

Bottle from BFC... Dark brownish color, decent head... Strong nose of apples, bourbon, oak, dark fruits. Taste is nice... Smooth but warming, light apples, malt, oak, berries, spices and just the right touch of bourbon... Twelve percent really? Well hidden. Nice texture....really easy to drink. Overall a nice beer to sip on and watch the phillies kick ass in the postseason. Go Phillies! Thanks Jake! Get your self some...

Source:750 mL bottle at a tasting in Nashville. 
Glass:Fullers snifter. 
Appearance:Dark brown pour with almost no head.  
Aroma:Spices, bourbon and caramel. 
Flavor:Chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, spices and caramel. 
Palate:Full body with mild carbonation.
Overall:Loved this.  Could drink it every day during the winter time.

Tap @ Barcade. Pours dark with little to no head. Chocolate, oak, dark malts, light bourbon and berries all influence the flavor of this beer and allow for this complex aroma. Twelve percent seems very drinkable especially if its cold out.
Bottle sample at Noogfest High 5. Batch 3. Poured dark brown with a thin quick tan head. Aromas of caramel and fruit. The flavor has dark fruits, sweet malts, and light alcohol. medium body and dry.

750 ml bottle - batch #3; dark brown, clear, glowing red tints on the edge; tan head fades quickly; aromas of prunes, mushrooms, vanilla, oak; body is thin and a little boozy; sweet and rich and bourbon comes out more as it warms; some cherries and earthy notes too; quite complex with different fruits, the barrel, chocolate too; lots of bourbon, but never in a bad way; quite an amazing and unique brew overall

Bottle shared by juiceisloose @ otakudens Vero Beach Throwdown. Pours reddish brown with tan head. Aroma of dark fruits, oak and vanilla. Slightly boozy but in a good way. Bourbon flavor with dark fruits, wood, vanilla and some chocolate. Full body with mild carbonation. Very nice.
Pour builds no head but has surprisingly ample carbonation., Nose is hefty with Apple, bourbon, oak, molasses. Taste is very smooth with bourbon, a hint of oak, fruity, with a nice coffee finish.

750ml bottle.  Pours a deep coffee brown with a small beige ring.  Nose of dark berry fruits, bourbon, nose was much more complex than Im making it seem, just cant quite put my finger on some of the aromas I was picking up.  Flavor held some coffee along with light bourbon and some dried dark fruits.  Very interesting combo of elderberries and bourbon.

Thanks to Beerlando for this one!  Whiskey and oak on the nose with vanilla and sweet malts.  Pours very dark brown almost black.  Hints of dark fruit in the flavor with big oak and vanilla notes with some bouron flavor, hints of smoke and sweet chocolate.  Excellent beer!

Shared by Retorp @ CCB BA Bolita release, batch number unsure, probably 3. Pours a dark brown with a slight ring of head, a bit of lacing.  Nose of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, malts, toffee, hints of chocolate. Flavor just washes of dessert-like caramel, chocolate and vanilla, with a strong malt back bone, some hints of drak fruits, and bourbon and slight woody notes throughout, some alcohol is evident, but a nice boozey feel. Full mouthfeel, low carb, great sipper.

Batch 3. Pours a deep reddish brown color topped by thin film of bubbles that leaves some spots of lacing on the glass. The aroma is very nice with dark fruits, red berries, wood, vanilla, and a solid choco caramel malt backbone. There is hint of some sour mash from the bourbon as well. The flavor follows with more dark fruit, cherries, and figs all blended nicely with the chocolate and caramel. The bourbon and vanilla are noticed throughout but never dominate the flavors. Full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel with subtle carbonation the lends to a nice drinker. This doesnt feel like 12%, but you know its there. This is a really nice beer, and one that would go great on a cold night.

Batch 2.  Killer beer.  Theres the from level of beer and then it kicks in with a second level of finish from the bourbon.  There are many other layers of excellence revealed.  Lively but balanced palate.  Bottle shared at RBSG 2009 grand tasting.

Growler of the 06 provided by Greg at the Castleton release.  Pours a deep dark black with a thin tan head.  Fruit, berries, bourbon, oak, and malt on the nose.  Smells excellent.  Plum and malt on the body before a light malty finish.  A touch of alcohol on the finish.

A little sweet for me but overall a pretty good brew.  Brown in color.  Minimal head.  Aroma and taste of vanilla, figs, sweet malt and alcohol warmth.  I messed up and drank it during the summer.  It would be better on a cold snowy day!

Bottle 75cl. @ [ Tasting by cgarvieuk ]. [ Batch #2 ]. Clear dark red brown color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is berry, edelberry, oak, cask wood, grape, chocolate and vanilla notes, moderate to light heavy bourbon. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel has alcoholic notes. [20090411]

Sampled at Noogfest High 5. Pours cloudy brown with light beige head. The aroma is rum, berries, molasses, and caramel. The flavor is some dirt, earthy bitterness, and a dry and vinous berry character. The finish is very dry. Lots of complexity in this one, quite an excellent brew.

Brown pour with minimal head.  Nose of caramel, vanilla, come chocolate but minimal, and just an overall sweetness.  Flavor is solid, more vanilla alcohol, some dark fruits.  A different take on an american classic.  Pretty good, hope to try again someday.

The Nor Easter has arrived with a massive tidal wave of flavor. The dark clouds formed on my glass depict the lace that others may see instead. The high winds of pleasure simply blow me away! Better tie me down! I do not care to move because I see a massive  precipitation forecast. It will rain down drops of delight. I stick out my tongue and taste dark fruits and raisins and wonderful splashes of chocolate fill my taste buds. Willy Wonka, who I know is a Republican secretly, would be impressed. The appearance is Lenny Kravitz a dark brown but not totally black. I am taken back to the days of my youth when I would stick my head in a bowl of brown sugar and start licking.
