Thick, sweet, moderately boozy mouthfeel - just awesome stuff.

Bottle 750ml?  
Appearance :Mocha brown with black tint, small crystal, sparkly crown.3+
Nose : Front, hint of vanilla, middle vinous alcohol. Deep aroma.7+Flavour/Palate: quietly soft with noted strength, chewy with drier alcohol spiced with good does of vanilla. Soft truffle at finish. Think of gourmet chocolate with vodka. Very good sipper.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma consists of berries, grape, chocolate, and bourbon.  It pours a dark brown with very faint red hilights and a moderate tan head that fades somewhat quickly.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of berries and quickly turns to moderate bourbon.  The finish has some faint roasted chocolate flavors, fruity tanginess, nuts,  and light alcohol.  Medium-full bodied with light carbonation.
Poured black with brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and alcohol. The taste was pretty complex. A nice roasted flavor with hints of fruit and alcohol. Not harsh at all. Very smooth.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of markgugs. Pours completely dark brown and almost opaque, theres a warm, reddish glow underneath with a light brown head. Distinct and lovely aroma of bourbon and dried fruit. Rather full-bodied with plenty of sweet, roasted malt, vanilla and oak accents. The bourbon really shines all through also flashing quite some alcohol in the finish. Quite interesting. 100807

Bottle at Blind Tiger NYC- I figured "when will I have a chance to thry this again" so I ordered the 750 ml bottle even though my wife wouldnt think of sharing it with me (she was content with the tap Golden Monkey). This was about as close to wine as beer gets in my experience. I now understand the term vinous. This is a dark ale with a stout like color and consistency but with a belgian flavor that veers into dark red wine territory. Quite enjoyable but I think I would have appreciated it more if it wasnt 92 degrees outside. I only finished half the bottle and ended up giving the rest to a guy seated at the bar.

Thanks to Tim for sharing
A very dark brown pour with a complexity of flavors from the bourbon barrel aging a berries, this is a tasty one.

Thanks to  dmac621  for sending this bottle my way.  Sampled at 7/17/07 STL beer gathering.  Pours very dark brown with a crimson hue and brown head.  The aroma has very smooth oak, vanilla, perfume, dark berry (elderberry I presume) and smooth caramel.  Medium body with sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts sharp and alcoholic along with dark berries, some bourbon, oak and dark toasted malt.  The finish is very berry and dark in all flavors along with some harsh alcohol flavor.  This one will probably improve with age and mellow out, but it was still enjoyable fresh.

Tasted 7/17/07.  750ml bottle.  Deep brown opaque hue.  Skim of beige heqad.  Raisins aplums and vanilla aromas.  Touch port.  Full bodied and smooth.  Slightly woody smokey with vanilla notes.  Good burn.  Mild yet sticky.  Not too oaky.  subtle dark fruit flavors.  Thanks to vyvvy!

Wow, fantastic surprise.  Taste mellows out  into a smooth, deep imperial stout with a slightly harsh, sour oakiness. The beer is complex but could use some aging to smooth it all out.  Great fresh, probably even better aged.

Thanks for sharing, iowaherkeye. The body was black with an orangeish, tan head. The aroma was chocolate with some maple notes. Yes, the elderberries and wine character is present. I know that smell as I have tried several elderberry wines. The taste was milk chocolate with massive oak notes. There was also some sweet plums. A decent winter beer, but way too much for me. Absolutely a sipper if I have ever had one.

Bottle: Pours dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma, chocolate, roasted notes, some fruit, and a little bready. Flavor, roasty chocolate, brown sugar, some berries. The alcohol and bourbon come through a bit more as the beer warms. Good stuff.

Black, impenetrable appearance with ruby shades near the rim.  Lasting crown.  Layered aroma heavy with bourbon influence.  Honey, blueberry muffins, boysenberry syrup and brown sugar.  A rich and bombastic flavor, notably subtle and streamlined.  The molten bourbon still dominates, perhaps a bit harshly, but it supports a colorful pallet.  Candied raisins, chocolate liqueur, mild licorice.  Finishes on a brilliant pulse of the burnt crust of crème brulee.  Palate is dense and long with the remnants of many berry reductions.  Immense and subtle despite its youth, and probably destined for true transcendence with a little age. 
Thanks Adam!

750 ml bottle - Batch #1 from a trade with The_Epeeist. Thanks Chris! Pours a dark brown color with a huge tan head. Aroma of bourbon, elderberries, and alcohol. The vinous taste is strong and overwhelming. The bourbon and alcohol are up front and predominate and really makes this hot brew hard to fully enjoy. I agree with what was stated already in the fact that this needs to be cellered for awhile so it can settle down a bit.

25 oz bottle, via adrian910ss, Batch 1.  Pours a dark mahogany brown body with some cola like highlights under a most beautiful creamy dollop of brown head.  Extremely fine bubbled visible carbonation.  A nice fruity and dense aroma.  Fresh squeezed elderberry/blueberry with raisin, heavy yeast influence, vanilla, and a nice restrained bourbon presence.  Whoa!  The bourbon is all over this beer in the flavor though, with just a light fruity hint on the finish, almost everything else is obscured.  Theres also a ton of alcohol, leaving a very warm finish.  Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a nice soft carbonation level giving a great creamy texture up front.  A little too much alcohol burn on the finish.  This started out awesome, but it just got too overwhelming with all that bourbon.  I couldnt bring myself to finish the whole bottle.

750ml bottle from MrBendo. Batch 1.  Aroma:  Rich maltiness with strong caramel notes.  Oak jumps out pretty strong with some woody, nutty, and vanilla notes.  Subtle bourbon.  Raisins and cherries.  Some yeasty breadiness.  Light alcohol as it warms.  Appearance:  Dark, dark brown in color with small chestnut highlights.  Medium tan head was full and foamy with decent retention.  Fair lacing.  Flavor:  Bready maltiness upfront with some nice caramel notes.  Raisin and cherry.  Strong oakiness with notes of coconut and vanilla.  Borbon and alcohol come through strong.  Sweet finish.  Palate:  Full bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Alcohol warming all over mouth.  Overall:  Theres some nice flavors in here, but the bourbon, oak, and alcohol just dominate.  This needs to mellow out alot.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 Batch #1.  Dark brown color with a slight reddish tinge and a nice size tan head.  Aroma is powerful and sweet - bourbon, wood, vanilla, some dark fruit, and bits of chocolate and coffee.  Taste has some woody & berry sweetness upfront combined with rich chocolate and coffee.  The bourbon flavor is prominent, but not overwhelming.  Alcohol is noticeable, but works well with the brew.  A pleasant and tingly aftertaste lingers.  This one is just a really well put together beer that, despite its youth, is complex and well crafted.  Im psyched to try this one as it ages and am very happy to see these guys producing such quality beers!  Rerate on batch 2 - 5/2/2008 - All the same goodness with a smoother, more balanced finish.  Wonderful.  Always good to see a great beer improve from year to year.

Aroma rich with bourbon character with subtle fruit backing, hints of alcoholic strength exagerated by bourbon aroma.  Dark brown in color with a rich tan head, good clarity.  Flavor doninated by bouron character initially then added dark chocolate and some ethiopian coffee notes.  Beer finishes clean with a strong warming sensation indicitive of the ABV.   Finish is clean and short, sense of alcohol persists as palate sensation.  Fully body with appropiate carbonation.  The highlight of the Captain Lawrence visit to my homebrew clubs meeting.
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: Thanks Todd for the chance to try these Captain Lawrence brews, I will be looking for more in the future. My #200 BIG BEER: Bottle and served in my Unibroue tulip: Pours a deep ruddy brown topped by a long lasting frothy tan head and excellent lacing. The nose displays a fruity element which I guess is the elderberry and some raisin and apple esters; a bourbon barrel influence (vanilla, oak, booze); hint of leather, tobacco and mocha malts vapours and even a note of peat-bog moss. The flavor profile starts with a quick punch of acidic and ripened fruits followed quickly by vanilla and toffee sweetness. The finish is sadly dominated by the alcoholic nature of the combination of bourbon barrel and base big beer. Just raw, hot and overwhelming to the point all finesse is lost. The mouth feel also suffers from powerful alcohol abuse, very dry on the finish,  peppery too. I would like to see what about 2 or 3 years of aging would do for this brew, for now I cant really recommend this beer unless to cellar.

25.4 oz bottle.  Dense and dark purple brown with a clingy tan head.  Grape and wood.  Deeper notes of raisin, bourbon and spice.  Wow!  This is one rich brew.  Tangy candied orange peel, dry berries and caramel.  Finishes like a chocolate bourbon toddy.  Tasty and intriguing.  Very satisfying but still a bit hot.  Ill be sipping this one all afternoon.

Crazy to think this beer is already up to its 49th rating, considering that besides the brewery location, this bottle only got out to a select few NYC stores. Good traders, I guess! So here I am, having drank it the first day out of the barrels, finally opening a bottle and rating it months after others.

Bourbony peat aroma, blueberries and jam, slight saltiness. Im not getting much out of the aroma. Pours very very dark brown with almost no head. Chestnut and almond in the taste, bourbon and fruits, fairly complex and very big. A little too caramelly in the finish is kinda boring. Still very hot, though for 12% bourbon barrelled beer, thats hardly surprising. A fun beer, though I must admit I dont really regret trading away all but 2 of my bottles. Though this should age nicely, I dont see that much more interest developing over the years. Certainly doesnt hold a candle to the wine barrel Smoke from the Oak, or Cuvee de Castleton, in this reviewers humble opinion.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 Handbottled 12 oz bottle from mystery swap 2.0 (thanks ty5592!). This one pours almost black with a tiny tan head. Nose is fruity and yeasty diacetyl. Taste is something between a bock, a porter and a Belgium. Lots of fruity esters, berries, apples, some chocolate malts,some peppery spiciness, some earthy hops, buttery diacetyl and of course bourbon. ABV well hidden for 12%..i would have guess around 10%... Carbonation is light (is hand bottled), body is medium.
3/29/08 rerate....orig was 7/3/7/3/16=3.6........
750ml bottle via Mys Swap 3.0 (thanks John_adam!). Pours almost black with red highlights and an average beige head. Nose is sour fruit..almost cherry-like. Taste is granny smith apples dipped in caramel/chocolate and rubbed with bing cherries and hazlenut..yes this is a bit complex..lol..and quite yummy. Body is full, carbonation is medium/moderate. THis is a wonderful beer that is unlikely to ever be duplicated again.....unique, subtle and way over the edge.

750ml. pours very dark with off-white head. nose has nice bourbon and caramel. hints of berries, oats. flavor has lots of bourbon, charred wood, dull berries, brown sugar, caramel. finish is hot with bourbon. a nice beer that sat on bourbon for too long, or shouldnt be in bourbon, i think a red wine barrel would work much better. solid but too hot. as this warms up it gets a lot better.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2009 Growler filled at Big Z - Batch #3.  Pours just about black with some dark reddish brown highlights along the edges when held against a light.  Moderate-large tan colored head that lasted until the end of the glass and left partial lace.  The aroma is excellent with lots of caramel, bourbon, vanilla and a few notes of elderberry coming through.  The flavor is equally nice with caramel, bourbon, vanilla, figs and just enough elderberry to be noticed.  Rich and full bodied.  Nice smooth mouthfeel, although there is a definite pronounced alcohol burn at the finish.  Excellent. 750 ml bottle - Batch #2.  Pours a very dark brown, nearly black, with some ruby highlights at the edge when held against light, with a thin-moderate light brown head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left spotty lace.  Very aromatic with lots of caramel, vanilla, and bourbon.  There is just a bit of elderberry in the nose, less than I remember in the first batch.  The flavor is caramel, vanilla, bourbon, light smoke and again just a hint of elderberry.  Some warming from the alcohol at the finish.  Rich and full bodied.  Lush, almost silky mouthfeel.  Although the elderberries are less pronounced in this batch as compared with the first batch, I think I like this version slightly better.  Excellent brew.  9-4-9-5-17=4.4 
750 ml bottle - Batch #1.  Pours a very deep opaque brown with a thin mocha colored head that left light lacing on the glass.  The aroma was wonderful with notes of caramel, bourbon, some very light smokiness, and of course the elderberries.  We used to have an elderberry tree in our backyard and we made elderberry jam every summer, so I recognized that component in the aroma immediately.  The flavor was equally wonderful with caramel, bourbon, dates, elderberries, and some lighter woody notes.  After a few seconds, a lovely vanilla flavor takes center stage and brings you to the finish.  Full bodied.  The alc
Pours a thick black with no head. Has hints of coffee, chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, bourbon, and oak. Finishes with a warm alcohol taste on the tongue. Thanks to boboski for the brew.

750 ml thanks to drewbeerme for this sample.  Pours a purple/black with a beige head.  The first note from the aroma is the dominant bourbon with some yeast, raisins,  brown sugar, phenol alcohols, and dark berries.  Flavors were once again a lot of bourbon, brown sugar, dark fruits, toffee, oak, and alcohol.  The flavors are pretty good but definitely unbalanced.  I think the bourbon is taking over here Id like those dark fruits and berries to come through more.  As it warms the alcohol is a little less dominant, but still it isnt as good as I had hoped it would be.

This was quite strange.Aroma has butter on the nose, weird.poured black with virtually no head.Flavor was sweet with chocolate.I found no hints of the elderberries though.Had a small warming feeling at the end in my belly.

Huge thanks to boboski for sharing this one with all of us at the Orlando gathering.

Pours a very dark brown, almost black but with soime light coming through. Small light tan head. Aromas of dark fruits, malts, sugars, and strong diacetyl. Flavor is chocolate, malt, some sweeter notes also, maybe vanilla. The berry flavors come through in the extended finish. Wood notes really arent super obvious. Alcohol burn is almost too much, very good but a bit green and hot at this point. Would probably age wonderfully.

Pours black with al ight white head.  Smells of some dark fruits, dark malts, some chocolate, and even a touch of some creamy caramel as well.  The alcohol is quite profound, especially up front, with big roastiness and chocolate attacking the taste buds.  Very malty.  A little bit syrupy and light bodied as well.  Very good stuff.  Thanks boboski for sharing this one with me.

Bottle... Opaque, pitch black pour with a small, creamy, khaki head. Lots of chocolate and diacetyl (Im talking about a "buttered microwave popcorn" level of diacetyl), but it totally works with this strong ale.  Also, notes of whiskey, smoke and oak. The flavor delivers light sweetness, light tanginess/acidity and moderate hop/alcohol bitterness. Medium to full-bodied with an astringent mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  Tangy, red hot, dry finish. Its way tasty now, but if I had my own bottle, Id lay this one down a little longer. Thanks to my friend, boboski, for sharing his bottle with all of us at his birthday party!

Bottle. A dark brown beer with a brown head. The aroma is roasted, fruity, vanilla, bourbon and wood. The taste is fruity, vanilla, bourbon, wood and alcohol. Medium to full body with a sweet warming finish. Very nise!

From 75 cL bottle. Pours very deep brown with two finger tall light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, slight earthy and yeasty. Flavour is malty, chocolate, bitter/sour to slight citric flavour blending with the a bourbon flavour of the alcohol. Thick alcohol mouthfeel. Strangely spicy and liqourice in the finish. I did not sense elderberries at all.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a brown shine under a lazing brown head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of brown sugar and prunes as well as hints of bourbon. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and oranges and again a light touch of bourbon. The alcohol is felt on the sides of the tongue.
Dark brown body with tan cover. The aroma is light berry, vinous, spicy, vanilla and bourbon. The flavor is bourbon, berry, raisins, toffee and vanilla. Medium/full body with very soft carbonation.

750ml bottle.  I was saving/aging this in my fridge for next X-Mas, but I couldnt help myself from popping it during the last "noreaster" about a month ago.  Just got around to entering this rating.  Poured into a chalice.  Stout-like appearance- pitch black with a light brown head.  Aroma vinous and oaky, almost sherry-like, but not with the same sweetness.  Elderberry essence comes through underneath.  Additionally, a bit of smokiness or charred leaf, with some alcohol vapors stinging the nose.  Flavor initialy of prune, molasses, and alcohol, like a rum/brandy soaked Christmas pudding.  Mellows out to a dark sweet bread/cake flavor with a bit of black peppercorn and some baking spices--clove, nutmeg, even a bit of vanilla.  After some more mellowing, it transforms into a chocolate and sweet dark fruit (concord grape?)combination. Smooth but earthy palate.  This stuff rocked!  It actually transported me in April back to images of snow, X-mas lights and the fireplace.  I can imagine this one improving with cellaring to even greater heights for next year.

Wow.  You better have a friend help you with this bottle because it packs a punch!  This super strong ale definately feels more like you are sipping a bourbon than drinking a beer.  Strong bourbon taste mellowed a bit with elderberry undertones.  This is a really good beer, but again I suggest you share with a friend!

750 ml bottle.  Pours a very darkish brown-black color with a medium brownish beige head.  Aroma dominated by bourbon with hints of vanilla, dark fruit and chocolate malts.  Taste is dominated by bourbon as well.  Underneath the immense borboun flavor,  berries, prunes, chocolate malts and vanilla can be detected.  This is a BIG brew and a slow sipper.  Very nicely done.  As much as the bourbon dominates, the other flavors are nicely abound.  Excellent !!

Bottle: Nearly black in color, large foamy beige head, sticky lacing. &nbsp Damn near thought this was a Stout when I poured it. 

&nbsp Interesting nose, first and foremost of Bourbon and Vanilla. &nbsp Slight graham cracker and Elderberry. &nbsp If you know what a 

Gooseberry is, this one smells moreso like that, with heaps of Bourbon in it. &nbsp Heavy Bourbon on the tongue, and I mean H E A V Y. &nbsp 

Notes of vanilla and alcohol are also apparent. &nbsp Alcohol being the major factor. &nbsp Course, its 12%, and it surely tells you so. 

&nbsp Big body, moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp I think this one would be more interesting if it were a Barley Wine or Imperial Stout. &nbsp 

Depends on how you like your Bourbon, either as a compliment to the beer, or as the "up in yo face" portion of the beer. &nbsp This is 

definitely "up in yo face"! &nbsp Lingering heat and Bourbon. &nbsp The underlying beer seems not as important as the Bourbon. &nbsp Good 

beer, but problem being you cant tell what beer is underneath. &nbsp Tiz clean, fiery, and quite warming, but any real aspect is 

overshadowed by the immense Bourbon aspect of this beer. &nbsp Good, but would be hella better if the base were a big Barley Wine or 

Imperial Stout. &nbsp Thanks John for this rare treat!

Dark brown/black, with a brown head. Aroma is dark fruit, bourbon, malt, vanilla, and chocolate. Flavor is dark fruit and berries, malt, chocolate, bourbon, and caramel. End a little dry. 
This is a really nice brew.

Pours an opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a well-lacing dark tan head.  Aroma of smoky sweet dark caramel malt with some roasted notes and a touch of piny hops with good earthy dark chocolatey complexity and a touch of bourbon vanilla.  Body starts fully sweet and dark caramely malty with nice plum fruity complexity and oaky balance with some bourbon and dark chocolate.  Well balanced and fairly complex, a nice brew thats more than the name winter warmer implies.
Pours a deep brown color with a light brown head.  Aroma is malty, spicy cinnamon, with some alcohol and bourbon.  Flavor is malty, spicy, and some bourbon.

Poured a very dark brown color with lighter rim and a small beige head.  The aroma is sweet, fruity, doughy, yeasty, and notes of bourbon.  All in great balance.  The flavor too was a perfect balance of fruity malt and bourbon.  great warmth.  Medium to full bodied.  The aroma had some tartness to it.

(750ml bottle, thanks kmweaver) Medium tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, vanilla/bourbon, oak, light blueberry, caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, berry, caramel, some Bourbon.  Medium-full body, low carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 My Bottom Line:
Wise elderberry vinosity teams up with an equally sagacious bourbon/vanilla sweetness to render even more complexity and flavor to the chocolatey roastiness of this serene strong ale. Of the utmost class, this fascinating masterpiece of Scott Vassaros should get as much attention as Tomme Arthurs own heavenly creations. 

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A lasting sheet of foam garnishes the mauve blackness.
-Its fruitiness (elderberries, black grapes, blackberries, etc.) is simply sexy.
-Alcohol is always well hidden, while contributing to the soulwarming experience.
-Subtle leafy hops decorate the finish.
-This is so drinkable for a beer this size!
-The licorice and vanilla apport of the bourbon barrel is well placed.
-Batch #1 was as enthralling as Batch #2, even though the barrels have been changed. Mesmerizing.

Bottles; Batch #1 and #2.

On-tap at the Ginger Man in NYC.Black with little head, chocolate and bourbon in aroma.   This is some crafting of fruitiness, bourbon, malt and hops.  Not one overpowers the other.  This is a slow sipper, as in hours, and in that regard I could not finish it.  I would want to share another bottle, and I would like to try it again.  Low carbonation, woody, quite complex, with a bit of sourness in the finish.

Kens Thirsty Thursday Throw Down - Deep brownish black, creamy light tan head.  Rich nose of bourbon berry, vanilla, wood, and hints of coconut.  Flavor pulls out woody vanilla bourbon notes that lie on a bed of boozy berries.  Had a light bitterness rounding this off to keep the malt in check.  Full bodied, medium carbonation, warming finish.  Good stuff now, but age will really pull it together well.  Thanks for sharing Ken

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2013 Sample from a 750ml bottle.  Black body with a tan and toast colored head.  Weird cream and liquer nose, strong smelling, with bourbon and blueberry and dough scents.  Sour and strange flavor, yeasty blueberry and pancake batter, boozy and strong.

750 mL bottle, courtesy of Dickinsonbeer.  Thanks, Paul!!  Pours a dark reddish-brown center; light tan head with patchy lacing.  Buttery, bourbon aroma; dried fruits and boozy.  Strong bourbon character, buttery diacetyl mouthfeel: pretty boozy mouthfeel; layered, dark fruits, but slightly unbalanced and overly warming; evens out with some time in the glass.  Medium, bourbon and buttery finish.

Good sized nice dense head of creamy and very fine bubbles.  Light brown in color and hangs around for a while.  Wow, potent aroma with lots of dark ripe fruit (cherry), vanilla, butterscotch, bourbon, sweet malts and caramel.  Very dark bown in color.  Rich and powerful flavor with a bourbon kick that is a little too noticable.  Needs a little more sticky malts to take up some of the alcohol.  VERY warming all the way down.  12% that kicks you in the butt!  Malty and sweet with more dark fruit (prunes) vanilla, butter and a dry and vinuous palate.  It is going to be tough to finish this bottle.  Finishes dry and very hot.  A pretty damn good brew.  Wonderful up front and needs to settle a bit and lose some of the alcohol prominence.

On tap at Mugs. Dark brown, almost black in color with a medium sized tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, sweet malt, caramel and a vinous smell that most be the elderberries. Flavor starts of mildly sweet and malty with the bourbon coming on lightly along with some oak, vanilla and again that wine-like flavor that I will attribute to the elderberries. Very good and should be excellent after sitting in the bottle for a while.

thickish dark tan foamy head, goes quickly.  blackish brown body, dark chesnut at edges.  aroma is dark berries, sweet bready malt, and a little yeasty too.  also vinuous like a dry cabernet.  some other dark fruits and faint licorice as well.  flavor is sweet bourbon malt, a little whiskeyish, then very dark fruits and vinuous like a merlot with strong carbonation, some hoppy bitterness and yeasty.  finish is bourbony hot and dried dark berries in the aftertaste.

Bottle from MaxxDaddy. Thanks a bunch, Max!  Shared with frumptydumpty before the anitbalas show. Pours a dirty copper with a dark beige head. Aromas are dark fruits, bourbon, what I guess are elderberries, yeasty, and brown sugary malt goodness. Flavor, especially as it warms, is very sweet with berries and bourbon leading the way, but overall very well balanced.  Thank you, ill have another!!

Color is dark, reddish brown body with a dark, tan head.  The aroma is very plum and prune-filled, yet with a nice balance of sweet lactose and roasted, vanilla malts.  A little astringency in the nose as well.  iT is certainly warming, and it is very delicious.  Im not sure what to make fo the boisterous, bourbon-burning sensation in my throat - I wasnt quite expecting such a punch.  The flavor is good, though, filled with bourbon, yet it has a pleasant earthiness to it.  I would like to try this one in a few years, for sure.

Poured an opaque blackish-brown hue with a tan head, which had no real retention.  Aroma was fruity with a sweet background, some peat notes.  Flavor was full initially i could sense coccoa, some really vinous characters are present with a somewhat almost peat-like charachter.  Alcohol was  subtle yet present.

750ml bottle acquired in trade with jjpm74 (thanks!). Bottle labeled batch 1. Poured a dark, dark brown color with a large sized off white head. Aromas of wood, nuts, chocolate, roast, light vanilla, and a very light berry/fruitiness. Every once and a while, I also thought I was getting some pine. Tastes of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, brown sugar, and had an all around vinous characteristic as well. Alcohol well hidden (Im pretty sure Ill be feeling buzzed after drinking this one myself though!).

Draft at HDG. Deep dark brown in color with a nice off white fluffy head. Bourbon, smokey aroma. Caramel notes. Smokey vineous vanilla flavor. Malty fruity notes. Finish is fruity and sweet. Full bodied.  Strong tasting and needs to age for some time.  Very nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Vertical tasting November 2010 - 
Batch 4 - Soft bourbon - lots of cocoa and bittersweet chocolate.  Softly herbal but the floral not is quite subdued.  Loads of bourbon and soft tartness.
Batch 3 - Oily and oaky but not all that bourbony.  A touch of barrel-aged wildness.  Softly sweet and a little bit fruity.  Oaky with a kiss of light peppery flavour.
Batch 2 - Softly sweet with a lot of dried raisin character.  Tartness with a little bit of dried fruit as well.  A touch of cherry and cocoa.  Mmmm - favourite of the lot.
Batch 1 - Deeply cocoaish on the nose.  Ethanol and a lot of cocoa as well.  Some plumminess.  Fairly oaky still although the oak is restrained.  Soft maltiness.  Its aging nicely.

750 ml bottle.  Batch 002.  Very dark black beer with a thick tan head.  Aroma is lovely.  Rich sweet aroma, spicy and lightly vineous.  A lot of dark maltiness, red wine and a bit of bourbony character.  A bit boozy, but the warmth really adds a lot of interesting back notes to the beer.  Lean body with a bit of soft dark chocolate.  Some molasses and some burnt sugar.  A little bit of woodiness.  I like this a whole lot more than I did the first time around.  Rich, complex and tasty.
8 4 7 4 16

Tap at Hop Devil Grill.  Very deep brown/black beer with a light tan head.  Aroma is deep and sweet, showing dark malts, cardamom, molasses and a touch of roastiness as well.  Light peppery booziness on the nose with clove and blackberry, but the body seems a little bit thin and its a bit too boozy for my tastes.  Quite light and peppery.  Probably my least favourite of the CL brews.  I suspect a year or so will improve this quite a bit.
7 3 7 3 14

Draft. Small, big bubbled head. Aroma is vineous and mostly bourbon. Theres a nice smoky flavor to go along with some vanilla. Theres a lot of grape in the flavor, maybe too much so. This stuff will age very gracefully. After reading the description, the flavor is elderberries, not grapes. Who knew? This is one kick ass brew though with plenty of punch.

You know, Ive never really cared for anything this brewery has made. I mean, not bad.. but never even close to justifying the pricetag. Finally this is about to change. Cloudy dark brown with a moderate head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is bourbon and vanilla barrel with chocolate, darker fruits, caramel, enough hops to keep it from being overly sweet. Throw in those berries too. Heavy body, some alcohol in the finish but hard to imagine 12%. Elderberries (although I have no idea what one is, I can tell they give it a distinctive flavor..) really made this one interesting. Only real complaint is that bourbon is a little too much. Otherwise, really nice job keeping a big beer balanced and interesting. As Borat would say, "Great success."

750.  Very dark brown in color with a very small tan head.  Aroma is huge notes of  chocolate, a moderate amount of dark fruit, and notes of oak, vanilla, and bourbon. Good amount of alcohol in the aroma also.  Taste is very full bodied, chocolate, elderberries/plums/raisins, light notes of pipe tobacco, vanilla, wood, with a moderate amount of alcohol and  fruit in the finish. Blackened purple with borders of chestnut. Creamy beige head quickly scatters, but remains tightly packed at the edges Jammy and vinous nose of blackcurrants, licorice and chocolate mousse. Whispers of iron, yogurt, charred wood, nougat and vanilla mirror one another in intensity. Trace presence of alcohol. Dense and lush carbonation. Bouncy nutty-oak lays the foundation that supports a tightly flavored and notably vinous mixture of mashed plums and mincemeat. Ensuing rush of clean alcohol and poignant, yet restrained, char gracefully penetrates the concentration of bright and supple fruitiness. Charred wood unites with the malts to generate a burnt fruitcake and chocolaty effect. Twang of leather and iron holds the sweetness at bay, as does the understated but well-defined char which bristles beneath the gooey residuals. Body is generously packed with polished hop flavors that coincide with the gently coarse bitterness which imparts ample body structure and helps lighten the thick yeast remnants.  Snug salty tannins and spicy char combat and enhance the beefy malts and perpetually-dense fruitiness. Resounding softness tempers the slight medicinal astringency. Finishes chewy and taffy-like, with a beautifully structured maltiness combined with a succulently-fresh fruit, peppery alcohol  and brightly estery accompaniment. Pretty impressive as is, but this ought to be mind-bogglingly good with a year or two of age on it. Thanks for the bottle, puzzl!

text: Tap at Mugs Split Thy Skull - fantastic stuff! - deep, dark burgundy color, with very little head, making it look like a nice glass of dessert wine - a nose full of oak and vinous smells, with the bourbon taking a subtle back seat - berry, fig and red grape aromas - very mildly sweet, with tart, tannic character coming through early to counteract that, and almost make the beer dry - lots of oak, but this character never becomes overpowering - like in the aroma, the bourbon plays a but part (thank god!), actually complimenting the vinous notes and wood with some vanilla flavor - dark fruits weave themselves in and out of these other characteristics perfectly - wonderful - I will buy several bottles of this for keeping, regardless of the high cost.
